description:
Borrowed from French nonchalant, from Old French nonchaloir (“to be unconcerned”), from non- (“not”) +‎ chaloir (“to have concern for”), from Latin
non (“not”) +‎ calēre (“to be warm”).

adjectives.description: nonchalant (comparative more nonchalant, superlative most nonchalant)

examples: We handled the whole frenetic situation with a nonchalant attitude.

entries.meaning: Indifferent; unconcerned; behaving as if detached.
examples: He is far too nonchalant about such a serious matter.
